import React from 'react'; import Chip from '@mui/material/Chip'; import Stack from '@mui/material/Stack'; import Slider from "react-slick"; import "slick-carousel/slick/slick.css"; import "slick-carousel/slick/slick-theme.css"; const slides = [ { step: "Research Other Competitors to understand weaknesses and strengths in their UI/UX design", image: "step 2.png" }, { step: "Create multiple personas to better understand user needs. Was able to determine that the most important features were: customization and intuitive features to reduce learning curve and transition time. ", image: "step 3.png" }, { step: "After determining what screens were needed and what features would go on these screens, sketch a wireframe.", image: "step 4.png"}, { step: "Convert sketched wireframe to basic wireframe on Miro", image: "step 5.png"}, { step: "Create first low fidelity prototypes and iterate as feedback is received", image: "step 6.png"}, { step: "Refine visuals and layout to create medium fidelity mockup", image: "Dashboard.jpg"}, ]; const ResearchBlog = () => { const settings = { dots: true, infinite: true, speed: 500, slidesToShow: 1, slidesToScroll: 1, arrows: true, // nextArrow: , // prevArrow: }; return (

Provenance Security

Overview

olution of any security issues.



Skills Used

{/* Slider */}
{slides.map((project, index) => (

{project.step}

))}


Our security analyst John logs in and lands on the dashboard, where is able to get a high level overview of the performance of his security.

A health bar indicates the overall state of his security. Data about alerts and endpoints allows John to briefly understand the status of his updates.

The customizable feature of these widgets ensures that John can personalize what he wants for his overview. John can also glance at his notifications to quickly take care of any alerts and issues.



On the alerts page, our security analyst is able to what types of alerts are occuring over a given timeline: Critical, Vulnerable, and Secure.

With a customizable graph widget, John will have the ability to customize the timeline over which he would like to analyze the alerts.

In a table of Unmanaged Alerts, John can get a glance at all the alerts.





By clicking on a specific alert, John is redirected to a separate page where he can dive deeper into his analysis.

Aside from details such as priority classification, status, timestamp, and more, John can also investigate related alerts.

By further examining the provenance graph, John can determine whether this specific alert poses a threat after which he can either resolve or escalate the alert.





Since the endpoints page is structured similarly to the alerts page, John can intuitively examine, sort, and filter for any further analysis.





Once John selects a specific endpoint, he can see any specific details about the endpoint and search for any alerts that originate from that endpoint.





Lastly, the settings page will give John any additional control over his experience on the cybersecurity platform.



); } export default ResearchBlog;
